slidelink.displaytext: Basics of Hazardous Chemicals and their Effects
Sources of Information at Work place
Sources of Information at Work Place

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Safe Handling of Chemicals.

Click START to begin learning.

This is the navigation guide.

You can click Script tab to read the narration.

Click here to view the abbreviations and references.

Welcome to Safe Handling Of Chemicals (SHOC) eLearning. By the end of this module, you will be able to:

•Describe Malaysian statutory requirements related to chemical

•Identify hazardous chemicals and their effects

•Recognise safe work practise in order to inculcate HSE culture in the workplace

Once the module is completed, there will be an assessment consisting of 10 multiple choice questions.

The pass percentage for this module is 80% and above.

Good luck and enjoy the learning!

Here are the contents of this eLearning.

Click the NEXT button to proceed.

Hi! I am here to guide you on how to handle chemicals at your workplace safely.

Let’s watch a short clip of chemical industrial accidents from around the world and our own plants. There are lots to learn from these past episodes.

Click the play button to watch.

Here is an overview of chemical industrial accidents from around the world.

The accidents happened in Japan, India, USA and China.

As you can see on the screen, there were different causes that led to the accidents.

The catastrophic incident in Minamata, Japan was related to release of Methylmercury in the industrial wastewater. It resulted in hundreds of injuries and more than a thousand people killed.

The incident in Bhopal, India was related to leak of methyl isocyanate from a processing plant. It caused thousands of non-fatal injuries and deaths.

The incident in Texas was related to hydrocarbon vapor combustion, causing hundreds of injuries and fifteen deaths.

The most recent is the incident in Tianjin related to overheating of nitrocellulose, which reported over seven hundred injuries and more than a hundred deaths.

We have seen global chemical incidents, now let’s look at our own incidents that had happened at PETRONAS.

The chemical incidents that had happened at PETRONAS consisted from chemical burn to mercury exposure.

As you may see on screen, the causes of these incidents were varied.

You have watched the dire consequences of a chemical accident. As we are dealing with chemicals on a daily basis, we need to know the legal requirements that we need to comply with. 

Factory & Machinery Act 1967 is to protect the safety, health and welfare of the people.

Next, Occupational Safety & Health Act 1994 is used to assure safe and healthy working conditions for working men and women.

Poison Act 1952 regulates the use of poison.

When it comes to management and application of pesticides, we seek guidance from Pesticide Act 1974.

Environmental Quality Act 1974 is focusing more on Scheduled Wastes Regulations 2015.

Finally, Road Transport Rules 2015 offers guidance on hazardous chemical travelling by road.

Click the plus buttons to view some regulations under some of the Acts.

We’ve dived into Malaysian statutory requirements. Now, let’s find out what are hazardous chemicals and its form.

A hazardous chemical has properties that is able to cause harm to the people and environment and damaging the property.

Click on the plus button to learn about hazardous chemical forms.

We know what a hazardous chemical consists of, and its form. Are you curious to know what is going to happen if we don’t handle chemicals safely? I know I am! Let’s find out together.

The consequences of chemical accidents can be categorised into four - people, environment, asset and reputation or P.E.A.R.

Click on each category to see more details.

By now, we can see the damaging effects of chemical accidents involving so many parties. The next vital step is for us to understand the basics of handling chemicals safely. 

In order to create a safe working environment, we are following the four steps of Safe Handling of Chemicals approach. 

The steps involved are identification, assessment and evaluation, control measures and recovery measures.

Let’s start with the first part in identification step - identify the location. The location covers:

•Chemical containers

•Chemical storage area

•Chemical process area

Let’s move on to the next part in identification – sources of information. There are four main sources of information at the work place – warning signs, labels, Safety Data Sheet and Chemical Register.

First, we will learn about warning signs and different types of chemical labels. Then, we will look at Safety Data Sheet and Chemical Register.

There are many sources of information in the forms of signs and labels such as:

•Warning Signs

•CLASS - Hazardous Chemical Label

•HAZCHEM Transportation Label

•Scheduled (Hazardous) Waste Label

•Pesticides Label

•NFPA Symbol

•Poison Label

The first source of information is warning signs. The warning signs must be present where chemical hazardous to health is used and stored. You may find them at these places, entrance to work site or area.

Besides giving warning of the hazards, the warning signs can be found with these features – bilingual and high contrast.

Besides warning signs, another source of information is through labels. Let’s look at the first label – CLASS – Hazardous Chemical.

When you receive your purchase order of chemicals from a supplier, the label on the chemical container must have several elements.

For container size limit above 125ml, there are six elements – product identifier, hazard pictogram, signal word, hazard statement, precautionary statement and supplier identification.

Meanwhile, for a smaller container size, usually below 125ml, there are only five elements in its label - product identifier, hazard pictogram, signal word, hazard statement and supplier identification.

In case you need to transfer a chemical to another container, you will need to relabel it.

Click the plus button to see a complete set of hazard pictograms and related hazard classes.

Another type of label is HAZCHEM transportation.

In case we need to transport any chemicals using public route, the transportation used must clearly display a HAZCHEM label.

The label used must follow these requirements:

•Name of the dangerous goods as specified in First Schedule

•UN Number for the dangerous goods as specified in First Schedule

•HAZCHEM code consisting of two or three characters

•Telephone numbers of emergency agencies, Police and Fire and Rescue Department

•Label indicating the class and subsidiary risk of dangerous goods as specified in Second Schedule

•Dangerous goods manufacturer name and phone number to be contacted

Click the plus buttons to learn more and see a photograph example.

Next is labels used for scheduled or hazardous waste. This type of waste is referring to any waste listed in the First Schedule of the Malaysian Environmental Quality (Scheduled Wastes) Regulations 2005.

The label usually consists of:

•Pictogram

•Waste Code

•Name of Waste

•Date Generated

•Details of waste generator, address and telephone number
Another type of label is for pesticides. If you are dealing with general workers who handle the pesticides for landscaping work, refer to this colour band and hazard statements.

The other label is the NFPA symbol. It consists of four colour-coded fields. They provide a visual representation of the health hazard, fire hazard, instability hazard and specific hazard that a chemical may pose during a fire.

For any storage or transportation of hazardous chemicals that have a certain threshold, this label will provide such information.

Next is label used for poison.

For Malaysia operation, the permit and poison signage are to be displayed at the entrance of storage or process area.

Other countries would follow their respective local regulations.
Let’s look at the second part of sources of information. The hazardous chemical information can be found in Safety Data Sheet and Chemical Register.

Each time you purchase chemicals from suppliers, they must provide the SDS. Its purpose is to provide you with information on the hazard classification of the chemical.

Let’s look at the SDS on screen for more details, shall we?

All chemicals manufactured, used or stored shall be registered. The chemical register shall be kept by individual department, together with SDS.

It shall be regularly updated to reflect the latest, at a minimum every six months.

It has 3 sections:

•Section A: Company information

•Section B: List of chemical hazardous to health

•Section C: Name of person who prepared and reviewed the registry

Let’s look at the common non-compliant labels:

•Label is not as per GHS or CLASS 2013 regulations

•Damaged label

•Faded label

•No label

On to the next step of SHOC approach – Assessment and Evaluation.

Click next for more details.

Before diving further into this second step of assessment and evaluation, it is important to understand the concept of health risk.

Health risk such as chemical hazard can cause harm to our health and potentially results in acute or chronic health effects.

As we are exposed to such chemical, we have the possibility for it being inhaled, getting into our eyes and skin, absorbed through our skin or being swallowed.

Therefore, there is the probability for that hazard to cause harm.

Click the plus button to learn more about the acute and chronic health effects.

When chemical exposure occurs, chemicals can enter our bodies in a number of ways through:

•Eyes and skin contact/absorption

•Inhalation

•Ingestion

•Injection

As there are many ways chemicals can enter our bodies, there is a Permissible Exposure Limit that we must know.

Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) is the average amount of concentration of chemical in the air which is allowable to work for a period of time. These limits are not distinct lines between safe and dangerous and are reviewed from time to time as new information about chemicals emerges. Country-specific PELs are often defined within local regulations and should be referenced for legal compliance. There is a potential of overexposure if the employee is exposed to more than Permissible Exposure Limit without a proper control.

Click the plus button to see the common limits based on specific chemical components.
The third step of this approach is Control Measures. Let’s find out more.

Control measures can be categorised into two – hierarchy of control and safe work practices with chemicals. The hierarchy of control consists of the most effective to the least effective actions. These actions are elimination, substitution, isolation, engineering control, administrative control and Personal Protective Equipment.

PPE and administrative controls are considered the least effective hazard controls. These methods don’t get rid of the hazard. Rather, they provide protection and reduce exposure, but the hazardous condition remains.

Besides the control measures mentioned, these are the additional control measures that you may look into as well.

Let’s look at another section under control measures – safe work practices with chemicals.

It consists of seven elements. We shall look at each element in detail.

For handling of chemical, it is important to refer to this checklist to ensure your safety.

For example, the technician is conducting grinding activity whereby he is exposed to dust.

Here is the checklist to be followed prior to conducting the task:
This is the process flowchart that you have to follow when purchasing a new chemical.

If you’re working in a confined space, there is a list of special requirements you have to follow. It requires you to ensure:

•You are fit and trained to work in confined space area

•The confined space work follows the necessary requirement

•Pre-entry and regular air monitoring is conducted by an authorised tester

•Adequate ventilation is provided

•Emergency response equipment is available

Click the plus button to see a sample of ventilation plan.

Hazardous chemicals warning signs posted at entrances of designated areas must be visible and printed in dark red against white background.

Hazardous chemicals must be stored and segregated based on Chemical Reactivity Assessment & Matrix.

Stored hazardous chemicals must be provided with secondary containment such as drip pan or bund wall.

Stored poisonous chemicals must be locked, and the access is restricted to only authorised personnel.

Click the plus button to see a full diagram of Chemical Reactivity Assessment & Matrix.

For any chemical that requires special handling such as asbestos removal, benzene exposure or mercury decontamination activity, you need to ensure that the work plan and procedure are developed in compliance to the government and company requirement.

Moreover, you have to ensure that the requirement is implemented as required before, during and after work.

If you have any chemical waste, make sure that:

•The contained, labelled and stored of hazardous waste must be according to the local and company requirements

•The hazardous wastes are disposed according to site Scheduled Waste Management

•Any issues must be notified to Company Environment Management Focal
We are on the fourth and final step of SHOC approach - Recovery Measures.

There are four recovery measures.

Click the tabs to learn more

Tab 1

In an Emergency Response Procedure, these are the actions that you must know as a control measure:

•What is the specific emergency protocol at the site?

•Where to evacuate and muster?

•Who to notify?

Tab 2

Decontamination is a process of removing or neutralising a chemical contaminant that have accumulated on equipment, tools or personnel.

Tab 3

When there is a risk of loss of containment, control measures such as secondary containment, spill kit or bund wall must be available at site.

Tab 4

In a situation where you’re injured (due to chemicals) or observe someone experiencing chemical related injuries, call for help (colleagues or passer-by).

Alert the Emergency Respond Team and tell them the location and nature of hazard via emergency phone at site or walkie-talkie.

Then, follow the first aid measures based on the nature of hazard.

Next, refer to chemical Safety Data Sheet and seek medical treatment as soon as possible.

Click on the plus button to learn more about the first aid measures.

We’ve come to the end of our eLearning. Here is the recap of the module.

Click on the ASSESSMENT button to test your understanding.
